articles.title: Chael Defends Tai Tuivasa After a Brutal Night
articles.description: When Chael Sonnen calls someone ‚Äúterrible,‚Äù it isn‚Äôt always an insult. In this breakdown, Chael explains why Tai Tuivasa embodies a rare quality that can‚Äôt be coached, drilled, or earned through belt levels: pure toughness. At heavyweight, Chael argues, there‚Äôs a point where skill acquisition hits a ceiling and fighters must operate within the limits of their bodies. Tai lives in that reality ‚Äî and embraces it. Chael compares Tuivasa to fighters like Derrick Lewis and even a modern-day Tank Abbott, emphasizing that Tai isn‚Äôt a technician off his back or a jiu-jitsu specialist. He‚Äôs a cage fighter. A street fighter. And that‚Äôs not a flaw ‚Äî it‚Äôs his identity. Despite questioning himself early in the fight and finding himself in bad positions, Tuivasa never chose the easy way out. Chael breaks down how many fighters quietly quit through positional surrender ‚Äî and why Tai simply doesn‚Äôt know how to do that. Instead, he fought through exhaustion, adversity, and doubt, finding his way back to his feet and back into the fight. Even in defeat, Chael believes Tuivasa discovered something important: he‚Äôs tougher, more competitive, and more capable than he realized. And in heavyweight MMA, that may be the rarest commodity of all. articles.title: Chael Sonnen Praises Oban Elliott‚Äôs Will to Win
articles.description: Photo Credit - https://www.instagram.com/mishaparsons Bad Guy Inc merch now available at https://BadGuyInc.com Chael Sonnen doesn‚Äôt hand out praise lightly ‚Äî but after watching Oon Elliott compete, he didn‚Äôt hesitate. In this breakdown, Chael reacts to the performance of Oon Elliott, focusing not on technique or tactics, but on something far more difficult to measure: willingness. Chael explains how fights are often decided not by skill, but by a moment where one athlete separates from their desire to continue ‚Äî even for a single second. According to Chael, Elliott didn‚Äôt lose because he quit. He lost because he got caught in a position ‚Äî and even then, he never stopped fighting. He never surrendered. He went all the way to sleep still trying to escape. Chael also breaks down why early submissions can happen, how sweat and friction change outcomes in MMA, and why the same fight might not produce the same result twice. He points to the pressure of media obligations, expectations, and career stakes ‚Äî and why Elliott handled all of it the right way. If Chael had to choose one fighter from the card based purely on will, sacrifice, and competitive spirit, his answer is clear. This is why Oon Elliott earned Chael Sonnen‚Äôs respect. Subscribe for more fight breakdowns and real talk from Chael Sonnen. #UFC #OonElliott #ChaelSonnen #MMAAnalysis #FightBreakdown #NeverQuit #FighterMindset Click here to subscribe: https://bit.ly/3FrHIPK Follow me on IG: https://bit.ly/3HY7BIE Follow me on Twitter: https://bit.ly/3tvY5J7 Follow me on Threads https://www.threads.com/@sonnench

articles.title: Dan Hooker Fought Brilliantly ‚Äî Chael Explains WHY
articles.description: You can go to my partner https://kalshi.com/chael and get $10 when you trade $100. Dan Hooker didn‚Äôt get outclassed ‚Äî and Chael Sonnen explains exactly why. In this breakdown, Chael reacts to the finish between Dan Hooker and Beno√Æt Saint-Denis, pushing back on the idea that Hooker fought poorly. According to Chael, this wasn‚Äôt a case of someone getting beaten up ‚Äî it was a single positional exchange that ended the fight. Chael explains how Hooker‚Äôs evolution against elite wrestlers changed everything, pointing to his confidence, his offensive wrestling, and his willingness to initiate grappling exchanges. Rather than avoiding wrestling, Hooker attacked ‚Äî using underhooks, body locks, and forward pressure ‚Äî which Chael describes as the ultimate form of wrestling defense. The breakdown also dives into ‚Äúanti-wrestling,‚Äù why offensive grappling creates defensive safety, and how Saint-Denis smartly shifted away from pure wrestling into judo-style techniques to capitalize on the moment. Chael gives Saint-Denis full credit for the finish, while making it clear that Hooker‚Äôs performance was one of his best ‚Äî even if the result doesn‚Äôt reflect it. This is a reminder that MMA isn‚Äôt always about who fought better ‚Äî sometimes it‚Äôs about who won a single position. articles.title: Chael on Volk‚Äôs Greatness: ‚ÄúHe Fights Harder Than Anybody‚Äù
articles.description: You can go to my partner https://kalshi.com/chael and get $10 when you trade $100. In this episode, Chael Sonnen breaks down the confusion surrounding the Volk vs Lopes rematch ‚Äî and why he never fully understood how it got booked in the first place. Chael reacts to the explanation floating around the MMA world (including commentary from Ariel Helwani), then explains why ‚Äúrewards‚Äù for taking fights don‚Äôt apply the way people think in this case. He also clears up a major judging misconception: a knockdown does not automatically win a round in the UFC, and he gives a real example to prove it. From there, Chael highlights what made the rematch more competitive than the first fight ‚Äî while still arguing that the division had clearer contenders. He points to Lerone Murphy and Movsar Evloev as names that made more sense, and explains why the UFC doesn‚Äôt book ‚Äúcurtain call‚Äù fights based on secret retirement plans. Finally, Chael gives Volkanovski major credit: his pace, his durability, and how close he came to doing something historic ‚Äî including his competitive showing against Islam Makhachev. Chael also touches on records and legacy, referencing **Jose Aldo, and why Volk keeps choosing the hardest possible path. articles.title: Everyone‚Äôs Talking About Tsarukyan #ufc
articles.description: Is Arman Tsarukyan the hottest name in MMA right now? Chael Sonnen thinks he might be ‚Äî and it‚Äôs not even close. Tsarukyan isn‚Äôt just winning fights. He‚Äôs winning attention. Headlines. Clicks. Momentum. Somehow, he‚Äôs generating more buzz than Ilia Topuria ‚Äî and Topuria‚Äôs a world champion. From dominant performances to viral moments (yes, even the food challenges), Arman has turned himself into must-watch content without even fighting. But here‚Äôs where it gets interesting. Tsarukyan came out and said if there‚Äôs a logjam at lightweight, fine ‚Äî he‚Äôll just drop to featherweight and fight for that belt instead. No begging. No waiting. No politics. Just opportunity hunting. Chael breaks down why that mindset is dangerous for the rest of the division. We‚Äôve seen pushback before when champs or contenders move up. Even Topuria had to ‚Äúprove himself‚Äù at 155. Khabib Nurmagomedov and Islam Makhachev weren‚Äôt quick to hand out opportunities. But Arman‚Äôs playing this differently ‚Äî he‚Äôs publicly showing he doesn‚Äôt care who says no. And that confidence? That‚Äôs leverage. When a guy is willing to fight anybody, anywhere, any weight ‚Äî the UFC usually finds a way to say yes. Is Tsarukyan about to force his way into a title shot‚Ä¶ or even two divisions?

articles.title: I‚Äôm Picking Volkanovski ‚Äî Here‚Äôs Why #ufc
articles.description: I‚Äôm not overthinking this one ‚Äî I‚Äôm taking Alexander Volkanovski. Chael Sonnen breaks down the rematch with Diego Lopes and makes a simple point: they already fought, and there was nothing controversial about it. Five clear rounds. Dominant. Decisive. Volk controlled the pace, the pressure, and the fight from start to finish. So why are people suddenly acting like this is a toss-up? Yes, Lopes hits hard. And yes, power is always the great equalizer. Chael admits that‚Äôs the one danger ‚Äî because the only times we‚Äôve seen Volkanovski lose, it came from someone landing something big. But beating Volk isn‚Äôt just about power. It‚Äôs about matching ‚Äî and exceeding ‚Äî his pace for 25 minutes. That‚Äôs a different problem entirely. Very few fighters in the world can even attempt that. Islam Makhachev did. Most can‚Äôt. Ilia Topuria didn‚Äôt match the pace ‚Äî he just found the shot. That‚Äôs lightning in a bottle, not a strategy. If Lopes is going to win, it has to be with one punch. Because round after round? That‚Äôs Volkanovski‚Äôs world. Sometimes the smart pick is the obvious one.

articles.description: It‚Äôs time for Ask Uncle Chael ‚Äî and Chael Sonnen doesn‚Äôt dodge the hard questions. articles.title: The Fastest Way to NOT Get Signed by UFC
articles.description: You can go to my partner https://kalshi.com/chael and get $10 when you trade $100. Chael Sonnen tells a story about watching a near-perfect post-fight promo on UFC Fight Pass ‚Äî and then watching the fighter take one fatal detour. While traveling and watching fights, Chael sees a lightweight grab the mic with a polished, rehearsed message that somehow sounds natural. The delivery is smooth. The structure is right. There‚Äôs even a clear call-to-action aimed directly at Dana White: ‚ÄúGet your checkbook.‚Äù Then it goes sideways. Chael explains why teasing or ‚Äúattacking the boss‚Äù is the quickest way to sabotage your own opportunity ‚Äî especially when you‚Äôre trying to get hired by the very people you‚Äôre calling out. The moment goes viral, MMA media piles on, and Dana White responds publicly with the harsh truth: if you‚Äôre going to cut a promo like that, you‚Äôd better have just had a great fight ‚Äî and this wasn‚Äôt one. Chael breaks down what worked, what didn‚Äôt, and the real lesson for fighters: save the big promo for the moment you‚Äôve earned it‚Ä¶ and get better advisers. articles.title: Chael Sonnen Explains Why Dan Hooker Wins...
articles.description: Dan Hooker versus Beno√Æt Saint Denis looks explosive on paper ‚Äî but according to Chael Sonnen, the matchup heavily favors Hooker. While many fans expect Saint Denis to drag this fight to the ground, Chael explains why that game plan may not be realistic, especially over three rounds. In this breakdown, Chael Sonnen walks through the key stylistic clash between Dan Hooker and Beno√Æt Saint Denis, focusing on output, durability, and where each fighter is most dangerous. Saint Denis brings pressure, power, and endurance ‚Äî but beating Hooker requires something very specific: overwhelming grappling control. And that‚Äôs where Chael sees the problem. Hooker is comfortable on the feet, hard to hurt, and no longer the vulnerable wrestler many fans remember from earlier in his career. After battles with elite grapplers, Hooker has proven he can survive bad positions, keep output high, and turn adversity into momentum. In a three-round fight, Chael believes those traits matter more than ever. This is a classic endurance matchup, but when championship rounds are taken off the table, Chael argues the advantage shifts decisively. Expect exchanges, pressure, and moments ‚Äî but don‚Äôt be surprised if Hooker‚Äôs pace and comfort in chaos make the difference. Watch the full breakdown and hear why Chael Sonnen is confidently backing Dan Hooker. articles.title: Chael Sonnen: "Volkanovski Wins Again"
articles.description: Alexander Volkanovski and Diego Lopez don‚Äôt require guesswork ‚Äî they already fought. And according to Chael Sonnen, that matters more than any theory or hype heading into the rematch. In this breakdown, Chael Sonnen explains why Alexander Volkanovski remains the clear favorite against Diego Lopes, despite questions about momentum, narrative, and opportunity. Their first meeting wasn‚Äôt controversial. It wasn‚Äôt close. Volkanovski controlled the pace, the positioning, and the conditioning across five dominant rounds. Chael acknowledges why the fight was made again ‚Äî someone in a decision-making role believes there‚Äôs a better version of Lopez. A more aggressive version. A version willing to pressure Volkanovski instead of reacting to him. That belief alone is enough to make the matchup interesting. But belief isn‚Äôt evidence. For Lopez to win, Chael argues he must do something only a few fighters in the world have managed: out-pressure Volkanovski. Not match his pace ‚Äî exceed it. And that requires elite conditioning, sustained aggression, and the willingness to walk forward without hesitation. In their first fight, Lopez didn‚Äôt do that. He allowed Volkanovski to lead, to control the dance, and to dictate every exchange. With limited time between fights, Chael questions whether Lopez could realistically make the conditioning leap required to reverse the outcome. Power always gives a fighter a chance ‚Äî but history shows Volkanovski only loses when he‚Äôs put down decisively. That‚Äôs why Chael Sonnen is making the same pick again. articles.title: Honest Chael Hurt Volk‚Äôs Feelings...
articles.description: You can go to my partner https://kalshi.com/chael and get $10 when you trade $100. Alexander Volkanovski returned to the featherweight title picture under circumstances that made no sense on paper ‚Äî and that‚Äôs exactly why the moment mattered. In this breakdown, Chael Sonnen explains why Volkanovski‚Äôs championship opportunity was questioned, why the criticism was fair, and why the outcome changed everything. After knockout losses at featherweight and lightweight, Volkanovski found himself back in a title fight not by climbing the ladder, but because the division shifted. That reality created discomfort, debate, and pressure ‚Äî the kind of pressure champions either collapse under or use to define their legacy. Chael Sonnen argues that telling the story honestly is what allowed Volkanovski to have a truly great moment. When a fighter is doubted, dismissed, or framed as undeserving, victory doesn‚Äôt just win a belt ‚Äî it silences a narrative. Sonnen draws comparisons to legendary moments in combat sports where veterans were written off, only to remind the world who they really were. This is not about disrespect. It‚Äôs about stakes, storytelling, and why difficult narratives create the biggest champions. Volkanovski didn‚Äôt just win a fight ‚Äî he completed the story that made the win matter. Watch for a sharp breakdown of matchmaking, media pressure, and why controversy is sometimes the greatest gift a champion can receive. articles.title: Who‚Äôs Next for Gaethje After That? #ufc
articles.description: Justin Gaethje didn‚Äôt reinvent himself ‚Äî he reminded everyone who he‚Äôs always been. In this clip, Chael Sonnen breaks down Gaethje‚Äôs relentless, Terminator-style pressure against Paddy Pimblett. No tricks. No surprises. Just forward motion, nonstop pressure, and a gas tank that never quits. While plenty of fighters try to walk opponents down, almost nobody has the lungs to do it for 15 hard minutes. Justin does ‚Äî and that‚Äôs what breaks people. Every step backward drains you. Every punch loses steam. Suddenly your offense isn‚Äôt sharp anymore. That‚Äôs the Gaethje effect. The commentary team called it ‚Äúvintage Gaethje,‚Äù but Chael disagrees ‚Äî this wasn‚Äôt old Justin. This is just Justin. The same guy who‚Äôs always marched forward, eaten shots, and made fights ugly until opponents fold. Now the bigger question: what‚Äôs next? Do you wait around for Ilia Topuria, or do you keep the division moving? Chael argues the urgency isn‚Äôt the same ‚Äî and a matchup with Arman Tsarukyan suddenly makes a lot of sense. Because when Gaethje fights, you don‚Äôt stall. You capitalize. If you forgot how dangerous Justin Gaethje is, this performance was your reminder.

articles.title: McGregor‚Äôs Return Needs This Opponent #ufc
articles.description: If Conor McGregor is really coming back, there‚Äôs one name that suddenly makes more sense than anyone else ‚Äî Paddy Pimblett. Chael Sonnen breaks down the reality of Conor‚Äôs situation. Yes, Michael Chandler is the fight the MMA world wants. Yes, that‚Äôs the cleanest storyline. But if that doesn‚Äôt happen, you have to ask a tougher question: who is the right body to welcome McGregor back after four years away and a brutal compound leg fracture? Because history tells us something important ‚Äî you don‚Äôt bring a guy back from that kind of layoff straight into a five-round war with a killer. Enter Paddy ‚ÄúThe Baddy.‚Äù A legitimate contender at lightweight, a massive personality, and someone the UFC could reasonably move to a catchweight at 168 or 170 pounds. Conor likely isn‚Äôt making 155 anymore anyway, so why force it? Chael explains why Pimblett checks every box: name value, hype, youth, durability, and a fight that gives Conor minutes without throwing him into immediate danger. It‚Äôs not about rankings ‚Äî it‚Äôs about the right matchup at the right time. articles.title: Dana White CONFIRMS Wagering Flag Cancels UFC Fight | FBI Now Involved
articles.description: Dana White has confirmed that the UFC fight between Alexander Hernandez and Michael Johnson was canceled on fight day after a wagering flag was triggered. According to White, the UFC was contacted by Gaming Integrity Services, prompting the promotion to immediately pull the bout. articles.title: If Lopes Wins, It‚Äôs Probably Like This‚Ä¶
articles.description: You can go to my partner https://kalshi.com/chael and get $10 when you trade $100. Chael Sonnen breaks down Alexander Volkanovski vs Diego Lopes 2 and asks the uncomfortable question: how did the UFC end up booking a rematch this quickly after a fight that wasn‚Äôt close? Sonnen explains why immediate (or near-immediate) rematches usually happen ‚Äî controversy, injury, a flash finish ‚Äî and why this case is different. Volkanovski didn‚Äôt just beat Lopes; he won every round the first time. That‚Äôs what makes the rematch fascinating‚Ä¶ and risky. If it goes 5-0 again, Sonnen argues the sport is forced to answer whether this matchup should‚Äôve been run back at all. He also digs into what fans consistently underrate about Volkanovski: pace. Not just cardio ‚Äî pace as a weapon, the same way a handful of all-time greats used it to break opponents psychologically. Sonnen then flips it to Lopes and asks the only question bettors are really asking: if Lopes is going to win, does it almost have to be a knockout? articles.title: Alexander Volkanovski on rematch with Diego Lopes, overcoming Islam & Topuria KOs | Daniel Cormier
articles.description: Alexander Volkanovski MAKES HIS RETURN to the Daniel Cormier Check-In series, this time ahead of his MASSIVE REMATCH against Diego Lopes for the UFC's featherweight championship. After beating Lopes by decision at UFC 314 in April of 2025, Volk reveals that Diego had his chances in the first fight to win by knockout. Hear what Volkanovski has to say about how the second fight will play out, and why if Lopes doesn't make proper adjustments he'll be in danger of getting FINISHED. And don't miss DC and Volk talk about overcoming the Islam Makhachev and Ilia Topuria knockouts, his next moves after this fight, and when they'll collab on a ‚ÄòCooking with Volk‚Äô episode!
